alert.note: Alert for Hampden (Massachusetts) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 6:38AM EDT until July 12 at 7:22PM EDT by NWS Boston
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Connecticut...Massachusetts... Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hampden and Hartford Counties. Connecticut River ABOVE Holyoke Dam affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire Counties. Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire Counties. Connecticut River Below Holyoke affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex Counties. Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County. Farmington River At Simsbury affecting Hartford County. West Deerfield River AT West Deerfield affecting Franklin County. For the Connecticut River...including Holyoke, Middle Haddam, Hartford, Thompsonville, Montague, Holyoke Dam, Northampton... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Deerfield River...including West Deerfield...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Connecticut River below Holyoke. * WHEN...Until tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 29.0 feet, Flooding will continue to spead across low lying areas from Holyoke south through Agawam. Inundation of areas which are outside of local levee protection is likely. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:46 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 21.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 26.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon to a crest of 28.8 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight. - Flood stage is 26.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 27.7 feet on 08/30/2011. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 315 PM EDT.
